p: The UN Women (UN, 2012) estimates that women and girls make up 60% of the population of chronically hungry people in the world. This number is even higher in low- and middle-income countries where women and girls are highly marginalized. ‘Women are vulnerable on all dimensions of food security: availability, access, utilization and stability’, according to Oxfam (2019). This alone calls for applying a strong gender lens in food system discourses. Additionally, women form a core part of the solution in ending hunger and in ensuring food security for all (CARE, 2020b).
